He was afraid of her, but maybe it was because she looked poor and he saw all the sadness around her. This made him nervous about everything he said and did, which was hard for a guy who already felt shy.

"You’ve shared a lot about my brother’s character, and I appreciate that you did it fairly. I was worried you were too loyal to him," Avdotya Romanovna said with a smile. "I think you’re right that he needs a woman's care," she added thoughtfully.

"I didn’t say that, but you might be right. It's just…"

"What?"

"He loves no one, and maybe he never will," Razumihin said firmly.

"You mean he can't love?"

"You know, Avdotya Romanovna, you are very much like your brother in every way!" he suddenly said, surprising himself. But then he remembered what he had just said about her brother and turned bright red, feeling embarrassed. Avdotya Romanovna couldn’t help but laugh when she saw him.

"You both might be wrong about Rodya," Pulcheria Alexandrovna said, a bit annoyed. "I’m not just talking about our current problem, Dounia. What Pyotr Petrovitch wrote in this letter and what you and I think could be wrong, but you can’t imagine how moody and unpredictable he is. I never knew what he would do when he was only fifteen. **PAGE SUMMARY:** The conversation reveals concerns about Rodya's emotional capacity and the need for a woman's care in his life.
